title: Market Basket board votes to remove Arthur T. Demoulas
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Arthur T. Demoulas was removed as Market Basket CEO after board members voted unanimously amid corporate tensions.
Demoulas faced an investigation over allegations of planning a work stoppage and retaliating against board demands.
The board reassured that Market Basket's operations and policies would remain unchanged despite leadership changes.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Sept. 10)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: Abington's highest recent home sale was a Cape Cod-style house at 27 Camp St. for $710,000.
Acton saw a notable home sale at 123 Skyline Drive, a condo town house, for $860,000.
Amesbury's priciest recent purchase was a condo town house at 21 Bailey Pond Lane for $1,049,000.

title: Here’s who will be on the ballot in November’s 2025 City Council election
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Preliminary election determines candidates for November 4, 2025, Boston City Council election; at-large race includes Frank Baker and Henry Santana.
At-large candidates Ruthzee Louijeune, Julia Mejia, and Erin Murphy lead the race, each securing over 16% of votes.
District races finalized with incumbents such as Gabriela Coletta Zapata and Enrique Pepén leading in their respective districts.

title: Mayoral preliminary: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Boston Mayor Michelle Wu leads preliminary election by over 45 percentage points, advancing to the November general election.
Josh Kraft remains in the race despite a significant preliminary loss to Wu, plans stronger campaign efforts.
Perennial candidates Robert Cappucci and Domingos DaRosa will not advance to the General Election in November.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi, a venture capitalist, sued surrogate mother Rebecca Smith after a miscarriage, accusing her of intentionally killing the fetus.
The surrogacy industry is expanding rapidly, but regulations haven't kept pace, leading to complex legal and personal conflicts.
Smith changed jobs and moved to avoid harassment by Bi, who attacked her online and sued her despite a ruling against this claim.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm is healthy again after missing 65 games last season due to a fractured patella.
Boston Bruins struggled last season with a 33-39-10 record, partly due to Lindholm's absence.
Lindholm's return could improve Bruins' power play, which ranked 29th last year with a 15.2% success rate.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bills QB Josh Allen praises Patriots QB Drake Maye, calling him 'unbelievable' and 'bright' during a podcast episode.
Allen and Maye will compete on the field in Weeks 5 and 15 this season, showcasing their respective skills.
Maye, drafted No. 3 in 2024, completed 30-of-46 passes in New England's Week 1 loss to the Raiders.

title: MBTA debuts train design to honor historic New England railroad, with more on the way
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: MBTA launches a Boston and Maine Railroad-themed train with vintage maroon and yellow design on the Commuter Rail.
Two additional historic designs for New Haven Railroad and New York Central Railroad will debut by year's end.
37 locomotives refurbished since 2019 with upgrades like remote monitoring, cameras, and modern brakes.

title: Patriots could be facing off against their former 1st-round pick in Miami
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' former first-round pick Cole Strange signs with the Miami Dolphins off Cleveland Browns’ practice squad.
Strange played 29 games for New England from 2022-2024; injuries hampered his effectiveness during his tenure.
Miami's starting right guard James Daniels is injured; Strange could face Patriots in week two at Hard Rock Stadium.

title: Tufts to go tuition-free for families making less than $150K
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tufts University will offer free tuition for undergraduates from families earning less than $150,000 annually, starting next fall.
Families earning under $60,000 will receive a financial aid package with no student loans as part of Tufts' new policy.
The policy aims to improve diversity and access, funded by donor contributions, with $143 million allocated for 2026 financial aid.
